page.title: 16Leicester celebrates Diwali
page.content: {Diwali}is a{Hindu}celebration and is as important as Christmas is to Christians. It marks the victory by {Lord Ram}over the evil{Ravanna.}When he returned to his kingdom after 14 years exile, his capital city was lit to celebrate his arrival. Today Hindus light night-lights around their homes and tell the{Ramayana}story when they visit relatives. Elders give the young money and, in return, they show respect by bowing. For Hindus, Diwali is a special time when they eat lots of special foods, eg.{Coconut Barfi, } exchange presents and Diwali cards, as well as dance and sing. The menfolk gamble, having been blessed by{ {Lakshmi, the Goddess of wealth.}Ladies paint{Alpana}patterns on floors and pretty{Rangoli}patterns on their hands using{Mendhi.}The streets are decorated with fairy lights.
